message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Review of autonomous systems and collaborative AI agent frameworks
Paper Abstract: This paper provides an in-depth review of the latest AI agent frameworks, focusing on the comparison of their features, architectures, and use cases. We examine well-known frameworks such as LangGraph, CrewAI, OpenAI Swarm, AutoGen, and IBM Watsonx.Ai, highlighting their strengths, weaknesses, and applicability to various domains. Additionally, we categorize the frameworks based on their specific use cases, including general-purpose agents, enterprise solutions, and open-source frameworks. The paper emphasizes the importance of selecting the appropriate framework to build autonomous AI systems and offers insights into future trends and challenges in AI agent development. By analyzing quantitative metrics such as latency, throughput, and scalability, we provide a data-driven evaluation of the frameworks’ performance. Furthermore, we explore the implications of these advancements in real-world applications, including their impact on financial markets, risk management, and enterprise automation. This review serves as a comprehensive guide for developers and researchers seeking to understand the evolving landscape of AI agent frameworks and their potential for future innovation. Since this is very niche and rapidly evolving field with scarcity of journal papers and this work uses white-paper and model documents to organize this literature review for peer reviewed literature creation. Most of the developments discussed in this work is less than 12 months old. This paper provides a comprehensive review of AI agent frameworks by categorizing literature based on publication year, category, and field.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "autonomous systems" and found several relevant results. Here's what I discovered:

## Overview of Autonomous Systems

The term "autonomous systems" has multiple meanings depending on context:

**In Networking:** An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

**In Mathematics:** In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

**In AI and Robotics:** An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently. Additionally, an autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

## Research and Development

Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program (WASP), launched in 2015, is Sweden's largest individual research program with the aim of academic basic research in artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, and software.

## Key Challenges

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, and even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

I've completed a web search for "artificial intelligence" and retrieved comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Historical Background

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## AI Research Goals and Techniques

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics. To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Generative AI and AGI

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.(no content)Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Applications

AI is being applied across numerous fields including healthcare, astronomy, military operations, video games, art creation, and media analysis, among many others.

Would you like me to provide more detailed information about any specific aspect of artificial intelligence?

Web search results for query: "multi-agent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"}]

Here are the search results for "multi-agent system":

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy—agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous—and decentralization, where no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications and Types

Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents; however, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

Here are the search results for "multi-agent system":

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy—agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous—and decentralization, where no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications and Types

Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents; however, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

Based on the search results, here's information about software frameworks:

## What is a Software Framework?

A software framework is software that provides reusable, generic functionality which developers can extend or customize to create complete solutions.(no content)It offers an abstraction layer over lower-level code and infrastructure, allowing developers to focus on implementing business logic rather than building common functionality from scratch.

## Key Characteristics

A framework differs from an application that can be extended in that it is intentionally incomplete scaffolding designed to be completed through its extension points while following specific architectural patterns. For example, a team using a web framework to develop a banking website can focus on writing banking business logic rather than handling low-level details like web request processing or state management.

## Frameworks vs. Libraries

Software frameworks differ from standard libraries: in a library, user code controls the program's flow and calls library functions as needed, whereas in a framework, the framework controls the flow and calls user code at specific points, often via the Template Method Pattern.

## Common Examples

Some popular frameworks include:
- Electron, a free and open-source software framework designed to create desktop applications using web technologies that are rendered using a version of the Chromium browser engine and a back end using the Node.js runtime environment
- Tauri, an open-source software framework designed to create cross-platform desktop and mobile applications on Linux, macOS, Windows, Android and iOS using a web frontend

Gunther - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_J._Gunther"},{"title":"Distributed computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing"},{"title":"Exascale computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exascale_computing"},{"title":"Scalability testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalability_testing"},{"title":"Talk:Scalability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Scalability"},{"title":"Bitcoin scalability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin_scalability_problem"}]

## Scalability in Computing

In computing, scalability is a characteristic of computers, networks, algorithms, networking protocols, programs and applications.(no content)Scalability is the property of a system to handle a growing amount of work by adding resources to the system.

### Key Concepts

**Horizontal vs. Vertical Scaling**

Scaling horizontally (out/in) means adding or removing nodes, such as adding a new computer to a distributed software application. For example, horizontal database scaling involves adding more servers to work on a single workload.

In contrast, vertical database scaling implies that the database system can fully exploit maximally configured systems, including typically multiprocessors with large memories and vast storage capacity.

### Real-World Applications

An example is a search engine, which must support increasing numbers of users, and the number of topics it indexes.(no content)Hyperscale computing is necessary in order to build a robust and scalable cloud, big data, map reduce, or distributed storage system and is often associated with the infrastructure required to run large distributed sites such as Google, Facebook, Twitter, Amazon, Microsoft, IBM Cloud, Oracle Cloud, or Cloudflare.

### Distributed Systems

A well-designed distributed system is more scalable, more durable, more changeable, and more fine-tuned than a monolithic application deployed on a single machine.

Web search results for query: "latency computer science"

Links: [{"title":"Latency (engineering) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latency_(engineering)"},{"title":"Memory latency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_latency"},{"title":"Amdahl's law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amdahl's_law"},{"title":"CAS latency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAS_latency"},{"title":"Memory timings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_timings"},{"title":"Lag (video games) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lag_(video_games)"},{"title":"Latency (audio) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latency_(audio)"},{"title":"Network delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_delay"},{"title":"Memory hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_hierarchy"},{"title":"Network performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_performance"}]

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about latency in computer science:

## Definition

Latency is physically a consequence of the limited velocity at which any physical interaction can propagate. The magnitude of this velocity is always less than or equal to the speed of light. Therefore, every physical system with any physical separation (distance) between cause and effect will experience some sort of latency.

## Key Types of Latency

**Memory Latency:** Memory latency is the time between initiating a request for a byte or word in memory until it is retrieved by a processor.(no content)If the data are not in the processor's cache, it takes longer to obtain them, as the processor will have to communicate with the external memory cells.

**Network Latency:** Network latency in a packet-switched network is measured as either one-way (the time from the source sending a packet to the destination receiving it), or round-trip delay time (the one-way latency from the source to the destination plus the one-way latency from the destination back to the source).

**Mechanical Latency:** In disk drives, latency is the time seek time for the actuator arm to be positioned above the appropriate track and then rotational latency for the data encoded on a platter to rotate from its current position to a position under the disk read-and-write head.

## Importance

Perceptible latency has a strong effect on user satisfaction and usability in the field of human–machine interaction.(no content)Online games are sensitive to latency (lag), since fast response times to new events occurring during a game session are rewarded while slow response times may carry penalties. Due to a delay in transmission of game events, a player with a high-latency internet connection may show slow responses in spite of appropriate reaction time. This gives players with low-latency connections a technical advantage.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Latency (engineering) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latency_(engineering)"},{"title":"Memory latency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_latency"},{"title":"Amdahl's law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amdahl's_law"},{"title":"CAS latency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAS_latency"},{"title":"Memory timings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_timings"},{"title":"Lag (video games) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lag_(video_games)"},{"title":"Latency (audio) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latency_(audio)"},{"title":"Network delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_delay"},{"title":"Memory hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_hierarchy"},{"title":"Network performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_performance"}]

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about latency in computer science:

## Definition

Latency is physically a consequence of the limited velocity at which any physical interaction can propagate. The magnitude of this velocity is always less than or equal to the speed of light. Therefore, every physical system with any physical separation (distance) between cause and effect will experience some sort of latency.

## Key Types of Latency

**Memory Latency:** Memory latency is the time between initiating a request for a byte or word in memory until it is retrieved by a processor.(no content)If the data are not in the processor's cache, it takes longer to obtain them, as the processor will have to communicate with the external memory cells.

**Network Latency:** Network latency in a packet-switched network is measured as either one-way (the time from the source sending a packet to the destination receiving it), or round-trip delay time (the one-way latency from the source to the destination plus the one-way latency from the destination back to the source).

**Mechanical Latency:** In disk drives, latency is the time seek time for the actuator arm to be positioned above the appropriate track and then rotational latency for the data encoded on a platter to rotate from its current position to a position under the disk read-and-write head.

## Importance

Perceptible latency has a strong effect on user satisfaction and usability in the field of human–machine interaction.(no content)Online games are sensitive to latency (lag), since fast response times to new events occurring during a game session are rewarded while slow response times may carry penalties. Due to a delay in transmission of game events, a player with a high-latency internet connection may show slow responses in spite of appropriate reaction time. This gives players with low-latency connections a technical advantage.

Based on the search results, here's information about network throughput:

## Definition

Network throughput refers to the rate of message delivery over a communication channel in a communication network, such as Ethernet or packet radio.

## Key Characteristics

Throughput is the actual rate that information is transferred, which differs from bandwidth. The throughput is measured in bits per second (bit/s) or (rarely) bytes per second (B/s), where 1 B/s is 8 bit/s.

## Measurement

A typical method of performing a measurement is to transfer a 'large' file from one system to another system and measure the time required to complete the transfer or copy of the file. The throughput is then calculated by dividing the file size by the time to get the throughput in megabits, kilobits, or bits per second.

## Important Distinction: Goodput

It's important to note that goodput is the application-level throughput of a communication; i.e. the number of useful information bits delivered by the network to a certain destination per unit of time.(no content)The goodput is always lower than the throughput (the gross bit rate that is transferred physically), which generally is lower than network access connection speed (the channel capacity or bandwidth).

## Factors Affecting Throughput

There are many overheads accounted for in throughput in addition to transmission overheads, including latency, TCP Receive Window size and system limitations.

Here's a comprehensive overview of financial markets based on the search results:

## What Are Financial Markets?

A financial market is a market in which people trade financial securities and derivatives at low transaction costs.(no content)Some of the securities include stocks and bonds, raw materials and precious metals, which are known in the financial markets as commodities.

## Types of Financial Markets

Financial markets encompass several key segments:

- Stock markets, which provide financing through the issuance of shares or common stock, and enable the subsequent trading thereof.
- Bond markets, which provide financing through the issuance of bonds, and enable the subsequent trading thereof.
- Commodity markets, which facilitate trading in the primary economic sector rather than manufactured products.
- Money markets, which provide short term debt financing and investment.
- Derivatives markets, which provide instruments for the management of financial risk.
- Foreign exchange markets, which facilitate the trading of foreign exchange.

## Market Structure

The capital markets may also be divided into primary markets and secondary markets. Newly formed (issued) securities are bought or sold in primary markets, such as during initial public offerings. Secondary markets allow investors to buy and sell existing securities.

## Function in the Economy

Financial markets attract funds from investors and channels them to corporations—they thus allow corporations to finance their operations and achieve growth. Money markets allow firms to borrow funds on a short-term basis, while capital markets allow corporations to gain long-term funding to support expansion (known as maturity transformation).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "risk management"

Links: [{"title":"Risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_management"},{"title":"Enterprise risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterprise_risk_management"},{"title":"Risk Management Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_Management_Framework"},{"title":"Supplier risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supplier_risk_management"},{"title":"Risk Management (magazine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_Management_(magazine)"},{"title":"Supply chain risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply-chain_risk_management"},{"title":"Category:Risk management in business - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Risk_management_in_business"},{"title":"Behavioral risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_risk_management"},{"title":"Weather risk management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_risk_management"},{"title":"Strategic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_risk"}]

Here are the search results for "risk management":

## General Definition

Risk management is the identification, evaluation, and prioritization of risks, followed by the minimization, monitoring, and control of the impact or probability of those risks occurring.(no content)Risks can come from various sources including uncertainty in international markets, political instability, dangers of project failures, legal liabilities, credit risk, accidents, natural causes and disasters, deliberate attack from an adversary, or events of uncertain or unpredictable root-cause.

## Types of Approaches

**Enterprise Risk Management (ERM):** Enterprise risk management is an organization-wide approach to identifying, assessing, and managing risks that could impact an entity's ability to achieve its strategic objectives.(no content)ERM addresses broad categories of risk, including operational, financial, compliance, strategic, and reputational risks.

**Supply Chain Risk Management:** Supply chain risk management is the implementation of strategies to manage both everyday and exceptional risks along the supply chain based on continuous risk assessment with the objective of reducing vulnerability and ensuring continuity.

**Behavioral Risk Management:** Behavioral risk involves the identification, analysis, and management of risk factors in industrial and organizational psychology.

## Risk Management Strategies

Strategies to manage threats typically include avoiding the threat, reducing the negative effect or probability of the threat, transferring all or part of the threat to another party, and retaining some or all of the potential or actual consequences of a particular threat.

The field has significant standards and frameworks, including standards developed by the Project Management Institute, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, actuarial societies, and International Organization for Standardization.

Here are the search results for "risk management":

## General Definition

Risk management is the identification, evaluation, and prioritization of risks, followed by the minimization, monitoring, and control of the impact or probability of those risks occurring.(no content)Risks can come from various sources including uncertainty in international markets, political instability, dangers of project failures, legal liabilities, credit risk, accidents, natural causes and disasters, deliberate attack from an adversary, or events of uncertain or unpredictable root-cause.

## Types of Approaches

**Enterprise Risk Management (ERM):** Enterprise risk management is an organization-wide approach to identifying, assessing, and managing risks that could impact an entity's ability to achieve its strategic objectives.(no content)ERM addresses broad categories of risk, including operational, financial, compliance, strategic, and reputational risks.

**Supply Chain Risk Management:** Supply chain risk management is the implementation of strategies to manage both everyday and exceptional risks along the supply chain based on continuous risk assessment with the objective of reducing vulnerability and ensuring continuity.

**Behavioral Risk Management:** Behavioral risk involves the identification, analysis, and management of risk factors in industrial and organizational psychology.

## Risk Management Strategies

Strategies to manage threats typically include avoiding the threat, reducing the negative effect or probability of the threat, transferring all or part of the threat to another party, and retaining some or all of the potential or actual consequences of a particular threat.

The field has significant standards and frameworks, including standards developed by the Project Management Institute, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, actuarial societies, and International Organization for Standardization.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of enterprise automation:

## What is Enterprise Automation?

Enterprise automation encompasses several key areas of organizational technology:

**Forms and Document Automation**: Enterprise forms automation is a company-wide computer system or set of systems for managing, distributing, completing, and processing paper-based forms, applications, surveys, contracts, and other documents.

**Business Process Automation**: Business process automation (BPA), also known as business automation, refers to the technology-enabled automation of business processes. There are three main approaches:
- Traditional business process automation entails developing BPA software in a programming language for integrating relevant applications in the digital ecosystem to execute a given process; robotic process automation uses software robots to emulate human-computer interaction for executing a combination of processes, activities, transactions, and tasks in one or more unrelated software systems; hyperautomation combines business process automation, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning (ML) to discover, validate, and execute organizational processes automatically with no or minimal human intervention.

**Enterprise Application Integration**: Enterprise application integration is an integration framework composed of a collection of technologies and services which form a middleware or "middleware framework" to enable integration of systems and applications across an enterprise.

## Benefits

Automating paper-based processes greatly speeds up the time it takes to perform transactions, which results in fewer errors, rejections, and revisions—and frees up time spent by users on manual labor.
